name: PIRC DEFENSE
uci_moves: e2e4 d7d6 d2d4 g8f6 b1c3 g7g6
idea: The aggressive hypermodern defense! Black lets White build a big center with e4-d4, then attacks it with ...d6, ...Nf6, ...g6, ...Bg7 and later ...e5 or ...c5. The fianchettoed Bishop on g7 is a monster on the long diagonal. White often plays the Austrian Attack (f4) or Classical (Nf3, Be2), but Black has dynamic counterplay. It's the opening for players who love counter-attacking chess!
errors_white: Overextending in the center: the pawns become targets for ...c5 or ...e5
Ignoring the Bg7: this Bishop can become very powerful
Attacking without development: piece coordination is key
errors_black: Being too passive: ...e5 or ...c5 must come to challenge the center
Delaying castling: the King must be safe before starting counterplay
Exchanging the Bg7: this Bishop is Black's best piece
development: Prepares the fianchetto and controls e5 - always play before ...g6
g6 then Bg7 - the Bishop becomes a monster on the long diagonal
Attacks e4 and prepares ...0-0 - classical position
Quick kingside castle - the King is well defended by the Bg7
Nc6 or Nbd7 depending on plan - prepares ...e5 or ...c5
...c5 (attacks d4) or ...e5 (central) are the liberating moves

traps.name: Austrian Attack
traps.desc: 4.f4!? Aggressive attack. White aims for e5 and f5. If Black is passive, the attack is devastating. AVOID (Black): Play ...Bg7, ...0-0, ...c5! immediately to counter-attack d4.

traps.name: e5 Pawn Trap
traps.desc: If e5?! premature, Black plays ...Nfd7! then ...c5 and the e5 pawn is attacked. After dxe5 dxe5, the center is open for the Bg7. AVOID (White): Prepare e5 with f4 or Be3 first.

traps.name: Fianchetto Trap
traps.desc: Normal position. If White plays Bc4?! Black has ...c5! attacking d4, and if dxc5 dxc5 the Bg7 is very active. AVOID (White): Play Be2 or Bd3, more solid than Bc4.

variants.name: Classical
variants.uci: e2e4 d7d6 d2d4 g8f6 b1c3 g7g6 g1f3 f8g7 f1e2 e8g8 e1g1 c7c6
variants.white_plan: Solid development. Plans: a4 (prevents ...b5), h3/Be3, then central pressure or f4-f5 attack.
variants.black_plan: ...c6 prepares ...b5 or ...d5. Play ...Nbd7, ...e5 and look to activate the Bg7 with ...exd4 or ...c5.

variants.name: Austrian Attack
variants.uci: e2e4 d7d6 d2d4 g8f6 b1c3 g7g6 f2f4 f8g7 g1f3 e8g8 f1d3 c7c5
variants.white_plan: Aggressive! e5 or f5 to open lines. 0-0, Qe1-h4 and kingside attack.
variants.black_plan: ...c5! immediate counter-attack. If dxc5 dxc5, the Bg7 dominates. ...Nc6, ...Qa5 for pressure.

variants.name: 150 Attack System
variants.uci: e2e4 d7d6 d2d4 g8f6 b1c3 g7g6 c1e3 f8g7 d1d2 e8g8 f2f3 c7c6
variants.white_plan: Attack with 0-0-0, Bh6 (exchange the Bg7), then g4-h4-h5 to open the h-file.
variants.black_plan: Avoid exchanging the Bg7! Play ...a6, ...b5 and counter-attack on the queenside before White's attack.
